You are currently on this page - COVID-19 Communication

td.p: March 29, 2020
Greetings Arrowhead Families,

We hope you had a rejuvenating, enjoyable spring break, despite the coronavirus anxiety and uncertainty all around us! The Governor's/Health Department's 'Safer at Home' order is in effect at least through April 24. We have no word on when schools might be able to reopen. We truly hope to get back to face-to-face instruction/learning at some point this spring-- We miss having our bright, engaged, happy students in classrooms!

A giant THANK YOU goes to students, families, and staff members who planned and adjusted as quickly as possible for Arrowhead's first Virtual Learning week. Generally, it went well. We learned a lot during that first week ... from student and faculty experiences, from other school districts, and also from responses to a Student Survey and to a Faculty Survey. Based on all we have learned it has been decided ...
ARROWHEAD HIGH SCHOOL WILL IMPLEMENT VIRTUAL LEARNING WITH 4-DAY INSTRUCTIONAL WEEK, until we can return to face-to-face school.

Wednesdays will not include any direct or facilitated instruction, beginning immediately. See the linked calendar "Arrowhead Virtual Learning Calendar " for details regarding A-days, B-days, and faculty planning/grading/collaboration days on Wednesdays through the month of April. An updated calendar will be provided in the future, if Virtual Learning will extend beyond the end of April. The rationale for this weekly schedule change includes:

ul.li: Students reported to us that Virtual Learning during week one was intense. Many students require time to adjust to this new format of learning and more time to complete the work within this more independent format. We are sensitive to the varying degrees of students' needs during this challenging time. Students may use Wednesdays to catch up on work, finish assignments, complete assessments, take a needed break from the computer screen, etc.

Teachers need more time to connect virtually with their course colleagues in order to promote common and viable curriculum decisions in respect to instruction and assessment revisions necessary within Virtual Learning. Because the needs of students have been significant during Virtual Learning, this collaborative planning cannot be accomplished when teachers are trying to make themselves available for students.

Teachers want to provide timely, quality feedback on student progress. Because the teachers' prep-time during each day is spent creating virtual lessons, we must provide teachers quality time to properly assess student learning.

Teachers are still learning how to teach effectively online, how to use various technology tools, what curriculum should be modified, how tests/quizzes should be adjusted, etc. Additional time is required for ongoing professional development and collaboration.

The WI Department of Instruction will provide a waiver to all school districts who will not meet the mandated instructional hours during this national health emergency. Using Wednesdays as outlined above will NOT result in school being extended beyond our planned last day of school to make up those instructional hours.

td.p: Again, we sincerely appreciate your understanding and flexibility, toward your children and our staff members, as we continue together on this journey of Virtual Learning!
Best regards and stay healthy,
Laura Myrah, Superintendent & Arrowhead Administration Team
Good afternoon Arrowhead families and staff members,
I truly hope this is the last email from me for the day! This fast-moving COVID-19 situation requires yet another update.

Governor Evers has directed the Department of Health Services to close schools from March 18 (latest) through at least April 3. Unless we receive different information or directives regarding what it means to "close schools" (we are assuming right now virtual learning is acceptable/preferred), Arrowhead will move forward with:

ul.li: Monday, March 16: Classes canceled-- No face-to-face classes and no virtual learning (Staff members report as planned for work and planning.)
Tuesday, March 17 - Friday, April 3: Virtual learning implemented
Monday, April 6: Resume face-to-face classes, unless circumstances change

td.p: Please see the related press release copied/pasted below. If anything changes over the next couple days, we'll communicate again.

Have a healthy and enjoyable weekend,
Laura Myrah, Superintendent

font.style: font-family:Roboto, RobotoDraft, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin:0px
font.strong: Gov. Evers Directs DHS to Mandate Statewide Closure of All K-12 Wisconsin Schools

font.style: font-family:Roboto, RobotoDraft, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin:0px

font.font: MADISON — Gov. Tony Evers today directed Department of Health Services (DHS) Secretary-designee Andrea Palm to issue an agency order mandating the statewide closure of all K-12 schools, public and private, as part of the state’s efforts to respond to and contain the spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin. A copy of DHS Secretary-designee Palm’s order can be found here.

The mandated closure will begin on Wednesday, March 18th, in order to give school districts ample time to make plans for kids, families, educators, and staff. School districts, particularly those in counties with reported cases of COVID-19, may choose to close earlier than Wednesday. The anticipated reopening date is April 6, 2020; however, the reopening date is subject to change pending further information.

“Closing our schools is not a decision I made lightly, but keeping our kids, our educators, our families, and our communities safe is a top priority as we continue our work to respond to and prevent further spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin,” said Gov. Evers.
Earlier today, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services reported 11 new cases of COVID-19, bringing the state’s total to 19 cases, including one individual who has recovered.

“Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care,” Gov. Evers continued. “We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.”

On Thursday, March 12th, the governor signed an executive order that directs DHS to take all necessary and appropriate measures to prevent and respond to incidences of COVID-19. It allows the Department to purchase, store, or distribute appropriate medications, regardless of insurance or other health coverage, as needed to respond to the emergency. It also authorizes state funds to support local health departments with costs related to isolation and quarantine, as well as the use of the Wisconsin National Guard.
Decisions about the implementation of other community measures will be made by state and local officials based on CDC and DHS guidance, as well as the scope of the outbreak.
People should follow simple steps to prevent illness and avoid exposure to this virus including:

ul.style: font-family:Roboto, RobotoDraft, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; margin:0px

font.font: Frequent and thorough hand washing with soap and water;
Recently DHS released new guidance for mass gatherings and travel, which can be found at the DHS website linked below.

This is a rapidly evolving situation and we encourage you and the public to frequently monitor the DHS website for updates, and to follow @DHSWI on Facebook and Twitter, or dhs.wi on Instagram. Additional information can be found on the CDC website.

td.p: Greetings Arrowhead families and staff members,

Although we have no confirmed cases of COVID-19 at Arrowhead, we feel it prudent to help prevent the spread of the disease. After consultation today with Waukesha County Health Department and area school districts, Arrowhead High School will be closed for face-to-face instruction.

Beginning Tuesday, March 17 through Friday, March 20, student learning will occur virtually through Canvas, our online student learning platform. There will be no school for students Monday, March 16. Teachers will report to school on Monday for a planning day. Spring break will be held as scheduled, and during that period of time, we will reassess the possibility of face-to-face instruction after spring break.

During spring break, March 21 - 29, we again will consult with the Waukesha County Health Department to assess the whether or not we can resume face-to-face instruction following spring break. If face-to-face instruction cannot resume, we will continue with the virtual learning until further notice.

It is important to understand, teaching and assessing will continue during the period of virtual learning-- it is not a vacation-- attendance will be monitored and students' grades will be impacted. Much more information will be forwarded through email to students and families very soon. Staff members, you have already received important information via district email.
Thank you for your understanding and cooperation during this unprecedented time period.
Laura Myrah, Superintendent and Administration/School Safety Team

Hello Arrowhead students, parents/guardians, and staff members,
The COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic is a quickly evolving situation, and has gotten closer to home with a confirmed case somewhere in Waukesha County. To our knowledge and to date, the Arrowhead community remains free of cases of this virus.

p.br: As stated in the COVID-19 Prevention Letter emailed out on Monday, we continue to receive updates from our the Waukesha County Health Department and will fully cooperate with any requirements they put forth. This new safety document released today is being used by Arrowhead, and may be helpful to you, as well. As expressed in a press conference earlier today with a State Health Department official and Governor Evers, it is not recommended that K-12 schools close at this time. The Waukesha County Health Department will determine the need to close schools as a precautionary measure.

td.p: As a few parents have pointed out, several Wisconsin colleges have already canceled in-person classes. School districts operate under different protocols, as attendance in K-12 schools is compulsory; a required number of instructional minutes are required by law and very specialized plans must be in place for on-line learning to occur. Like all other school districts in Waukesha County, until we hear differently from the health department, Arrowhead High School will remain open for school.

p.br: In consultation with many organizations and resources, Arrowhead’s School Safety Team/Administration has been meeting frequently to develop a pandemic plan for this COVID-19 outbreak. If we are told Arrowhead must close, our plans for continued learning for students will differ depending upon the length of closure:

ul.li: If school must close for 1-3 days, it would be treated like a snow day-- any missed instructional hours will be made up at a later date, to be determined.

If school must close for more than 3 days and up to a few weeks, learning would continue through students and teachers participating in lessons via our online Canvas learning platform. At this point, please understand it is imperative in the case of conducting learning online that your child has home access to a computer and the Internet and can login to Canvas. If any one of these is not possible for your student, have your student stop by either campus library for help.

If school must close for more than a few weeks, we will use guidance from the Department of Public Instruction and other officials to determine if online learning would continue, if instructional hours must be made up at all, during the summer, etc. Much more information will be disseminated, should it become relevant.

p.strong: Safety Precautions in the Physical Buildings
p.br: Arrowhead’s maintenance staff has reviewed and are implementing the best-practice protocols, including the recommended cleaning solutions for COVID-19, giving special attention to critical areas. Should our absence rate jump from our current rate (which is the same as the last few winter/spring seasons), we would then consider implementing additional/supplemental cleaning over nights or weekends.

As noted in Monday’s COVID-19 Prevention Letter linked above, Arrowhead is monitoring the Center for Disease Control (CDC) Travel Notices. If a student or staff member travels to a location with a Level 2 or Level 3 or Level 4 Health Notice for reasons related to infectious disease, that person will be asked to follow a self quarantine. This means she/he should not return to Arrowhead High School for up to 14 days, or as otherwise indicated by the Waukesha County Health Department, after they arrive back in Wisconsin. In addition to international destinations, the states of California, Washington, and New York are considered “hot spots,” with the health department advising 14 days of self quarantine after travel there. Please be aware, locations are being added to the list on a daily basis; a destination may not be on the list when you leave for a trip, but may be added before you return home.

A few upcoming after school events have been canceled or changed. As decisions are made about future after school events, they will be shared via emails and posted on the school website. Please refer to an email coming from Arrowhead’s Activities Department for the details regarding the following events:

ul.li: WIAA Sectional Boys Basketball Game in Germantown TONIGHT, Thursday, March 12 will be allowing very limited attendance.
Arrowhead’s Musical Theater Nights TONIGHT, March 12 and March 13 & 14 will be allowing very limited attendance.
The Forensics Meet hosted at Arrowhead on March 14 is canceled.

td.p: This COVID-19 has created unprecedented circumstances, which are causing anxiety and many questions. We at Arrowhead share this level of concern and appreciate your patience and cooperation as we learn, develop, and share information in as timely a matter as possible.

Best regards,
Laura Myrah, Superintendent and the Arrowhead Administration/School Safety Team

March 9, 2020
Dear Arrowhead students, parents/guardians, and staff members,
We at Arrowhead High School care about the well-being of students, staff, families, and other
community members, so we are closely monitoring the national COVID-19 (coronavirus)
pandemic situation. To date, there are no indications of a local outbreak.
We regularly receive updates from our State Department of Health and the Waukesha County
Health Department, and will fully cooperate with any requirements they put forth. If the
COVID-19 virus becomes dangerously prevalent in our community, it would be one or both of
those health departments that would determine the need to close schools as a precautionary
measure. Below is helpful information from these organizations:

li.a: Coronavirus Factual Information from the Waukesha County Public Health Department
COVID-19 Situation Summary from the Center for Disease Control
Frequently Asked Questions and Answers from the Center for Disease Control

td.p:
In order to reduce the likelihood of a COVID-19, or any flu/virus, outbreak in our school district
and local communities, we encourage students, staff, and family members to practice healthy
habits, including:

ul.li: Wash your hands frequently for 20 seconds each time, which is the length of the
Alphabet Song / Twinkle Twinkle Little Star . Use soap, warm water and be sure to wash your fingertips. If soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer.

Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into the inside of your elbow.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth, and nose.
Do not share eating/drinking utensils.
Attempt to stay at least three feet away from people who display cold or flu-like symptoms.
All people who are sick should stay home from school or work, and should avoid other people until well.

td.p:
As an additional precautionary measure with spring break approaching, Arrowhead will follow
the Center for Disease Control’s guidelines as related to international travel: If a student/staff
member travels to a country with a Level 2 or Level 3 Travel Health Notice for reasons related to
infectious disease, that person will be asked to follow a self quarantine with self monitoring;
she/he should not return to Arrowhead High School for up to 14 days, as recommended by the
Center for Disease Control or the Waukesha County Health Department, after they arrive back
in Wisconsin.
Thank you for your attention to important, health-related information. As always, the safety of
our students, staff, and families remains a top priority. We will continue to monitor the COVID-19
situation and will keep you informed of any updates.
Best regards,
Laura Myrah, Superintendent and AHS Administration/School Safety Team
